column2: POETRY AND PRISON
column3: POETRY AND PRISON

column2: (Pall Mall Gazette, January 3, 1889.)
column3: (Pall Mall Gazette, january third eighteen eighty nine.)

column2: Prison has had an admirable effect on Mr. Wilfrid Blunt as a poet.
column3: Prison has had an admirable effect on mr Wilfrid Blunt as a poet.

column2: The Love Sonnets of Proteus, in spite of their clever Musset-like modernities and their swift brilliant wit, were but affected or fantastic at best. They were simply the records of passing moods and moments, of which some were sad and others sweet, and not a few shameful.
column3: The Love Sonnets of Proteus, in spite of their clever Musset like modernities and their swift brilliant wit, were but affected or fantastic at best. They were simply the records of passing moods and moments, of which some were sad and others sweet, and not a few shameful.

column2: Their subject was not of high or serious import.
column3: Their subject was not of high or serious import.

column2: They contained much that was wilful and weak. In Vinculis, upon the other hand, is a book that stirs one by its fine sincerity of purpose, its lofty and impassioned thought, its depth and ardour of intense feeling.
column3: They contained much that was wilful and weak. In Vinculis, upon the other hand, is a book that stirs one by its fine sincerity of purpose, its lofty and impassioned thought, its depth and ardour of intense feeling.

column2: 'Imprisonment,' says Mr. Blunt in his preface, 'is a reality of discipline most useful to the modern soul, lapped as it is in physical sloth and self-indulgence.
column3: 'Imprisonment,' says mr Blunt in his preface, 'is a reality of discipline most useful to the modern soul, lapped as it is in physical sloth and self indulgence.

column2: Like a sickness or a spiritual retreat it purifies and ennobles; and the soul emerges from it stronger and more self-contained.' To him, certainly, it has been a mode of purification.
column3: Like a sickness or a spiritual retreat it purifies and ennobles; and the soul emerges from it stronger and more self-contained.' To him, certainly, it has been a mode of purification.

column2: The opening sonnets, composed in the bleak cell of Galway Gaol, and written down on the fly-leaves of the prisoner's prayer-book, are full of things nobly conceived and nobly uttered, and show that though Mr. Balfour may enforce 'plain living' by his prison regulations, he cannot prevent 'high thinking' or in any way limit or constrain the freedom of a man's soul.
column3: The opening sonnets, composed in the bleak cell of Galway Gaol, and written down on the fly leaves of the prisoner's prayer book, are full of things nobly conceived and nobly uttered, and show that though mr Balfour may enforce 'plain living' by his prison regulations, he cannot prevent 'high thinking' or in any way limit or constrain the freedom of a man's soul.

column2: They are, of course, intensely personal in expression.
column3: They are, of course, intensely personal in expression.

column2: They could not fail to be so.
column3: They could not fail to be so.

column2: But the personality that they reveal has nothing petty or ignoble about it.
column3: But the personality that they reveal has nothing petty or ignoble about it.

column2: The petulant cry of the shallow egoist which was the chief characteristic of the Love Sonnets of Proteus is not to be found here.
column3: The petulant cry of the shallow egoist which was the chief characteristic of the Love Sonnets of Proteus is not to be found here.

column2: In its place we have wild grief and terrible scorn, fierce rage and flame-like passion. Such a sonnet as the following comes out of the very fire of heart and brain:
column3: In its place we have wild grief and terrible scorn, fierce rage and flame like passion. Such a sonnet as the following comes out of the very fire of heart and brain:

column2: God knows, 'twas not with a fore-reasoned plan I left the easeful dwellings of my peace, And sought this combat with ungodly Man, And ceaseless still through years that do not cease Have warred with Powers and Principalities. My natural soul, ere yet these strifes began, Was as a sister diligent to please And loving all, and most the human clan.
column3: God knows, 'twas not with a fore reasoned plan I left the easeful dwellings of my peace, And sought this combat with ungodly Man, And ceaseless still through years that do not cease Have warred with Powers and Principalities. My natural soul, ere yet these strifes began, Was as a sister diligent to please And loving all, and most the human clan.

column2: God knows it.
column3: God knows it.

column2: And He knows how the world's tears Touched me.
column3: And He knows how the world's tears Touched me.

column2: And He is witness of my wrath, How it was kindled against murderers Who slew for gold, and how upon their path I met them.
column3: And He is witness of my wrath, How it was kindled against murderers Who slew for gold, and how upon their path I met them.

column2: Since which day the World in arms Strikes at my life with angers and alarms.
column3: Since which day the World in arms Strikes at my life with angers and alarms.

column2: And this sonnet has all the strange strength of that despair which is but the prelude to a larger hope:
column3: And this sonnet has all the strange strength of that despair which is but the prelude to a larger hope:

column2: I thought to do a deed of chivalry, An act of worth, which haply in her sight Who was my mistress should recorded be And of the nations.
column3: I thought to do a deed of chivalry, An act of worth, which haply in her sight Who was my mistress should recorded be And of the nations.

column2: And, when thus the fight Faltered and men once bold with faces white Turned this and that way in excuse to flee, I only stood, and by the foeman's might Was overborne and mangled cruelly.
column3: And, when thus the fight Faltered and men once bold with faces white Turned this and that way in excuse to flee, I only stood, and by the foeman's might Was overborne and mangled cruelly.

column2: Then crawled I to her feet, in whose dear cause I made this venture, and 'Behold,' I said, 'How I am wounded for thee in these wars.' But she, 'Poor cripple, would'st thou I should wed A limbless trunk?' and laughing turned from me. Yet she was fair, and her name 'Liberty.'
column3: Then crawled I to her feet, in whose dear cause I made this venture, and 'Behold,' I said, 'How I am wounded for thee in these wars.' But she, 'Poor cripple, would'st thou I should wed A limbless trunk?' and laughing turned from me. Yet she was fair, and her name 'Liberty.'

column2: The sonnet beginning
column3: The sonnet beginning

column2: A prison is a convent without God-- Poverty, Chastity, Obedience Its precepts are:
column3: A prison is a convent without God- Poverty, Chastity, Obedience Its precepts are:

column2: is very fine; and this, written just after entering the gaol, is powerful:
column3: is very fine; and this, written just after entering the gaol, is powerful:

column2: Naked I came into the world of pleasure, And naked come I to this house of pain. Here at the gate I lay down my life's treasure, My pride, my garments and my name with men. The world and I henceforth shall be as twain, No sound of me shall pierce for good or ill These walls of grief.
column3: Naked I came into the world of pleasure, And naked come I to this house of pain. Here at the gate I lay down my life's treasure, My pride, my garments and my name with men. The world and I henceforth shall be as twain, No sound of me shall pierce for good or ill These walls of grief.

column2: Nor shall I hear the vain Laughter and tears of those who love me still.
column3: Nor shall I hear the vain Laughter and tears of those who love me still.

column2: Within, what new life waits me!
column3: Within, what new life waits me!

column2: Little ease, Cold lying, hunger, nights of wakefulness, Harsh orders given, no voice to soothe or please, Poor thieves for friends, for books rules meaningless; This is the grave--nay, hell.
column3: Little ease, Cold lying, hunger, nights of wakefulness, Harsh orders given, no voice to soothe or please, Poor thieves for friends, for books rules meaningless; This is the grave-nay, hell.

column2: Yet, Lord of Might, Still in Thy light my spirit shall see light.
column3: Yet, Lord of Might, Still in Thy light my spirit shall see light.

column2: But, indeed, all the sonnets are worth reading, and The Canon of Aughrim, the longest poem in the book, is a most masterly and dramatic description of the tragic life of the Irish peasant.
column3: But, indeed, all the sonnets are worth reading, and The Canon of Aughrim, the longest poem in the book, is a most masterly and dramatic description of the tragic life of the Irish peasant.

column2: Literature is not much indebted to Mr. Balfour for his sophistical Defence of Philosophic Doubt which is one of the dullest books we know, but it must be admitted that by sending Mr. Blunt to gaol he has converted a clever rhymer into an earnest and deep-thinking poet.
column3: Literature is not much indebted to mr Balfour for his sophistical Defence of Philosophic Doubt which is one of the dullest books we know, but it must be admitted that by sending mr Blunt to gaol he has converted a clever rhymer into an earnest and deep thinking poet.

column2: The narrow confines of the prison cell seem to suit the 'sonnet's scanty plot of ground,' and an unjust imprisonment for a noble cause strengthens as well as deepens the nature.
column3: The narrow confines of the prison cell seem to suit the 'sonnet's scanty plot of ground,' and an unjust imprisonment for a noble cause strengthens as well as deepens the nature.

column2: In Vinculis.
column3: In Vinculis.

column2: By Wilfrid Scawen Blunt, Author of The Wind and the Whirlwind, The Love Sonnets of Proteus, etc. etc. (Kegan Paul.)
column3: By Wilfrid Scawen Blunt, Author of The Wind and the Whirlwind, The Love Sonnets of Proteus, etc etc (Kegan Paul.)
